bibl.title: Letter from W.H. Hoffmann to Philip Showalter Hench, January 15, 1942

div1.p: Hoffmann thanks Hench for the reprints of his article and asks the origin of the word "fomites."

div1.head: Letter from W.H. Hoffmann to Philip Showalter Hench, January 15, 1942
div1.opener:
Habana Cuba,15.1.42
Cerro 1381.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I received with best thanks
the very fine reprint on Yellow Fever
which you kindly sent me. In this
form your very valuable work looks
much better, than in the original
form published in the Journal, where
it appears cut into ten pieces
like a sausage. I do not understand
how the Publishers show so little
respect for a homogeneous cienti-
fic work, which the reader prefers
to see as a solid entity.

With best compliments and
kind regards
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely Prof. W. H. Hoffmann M. D. t. o ps.
Ms
I see that in your paper you use
the word “fomites.” I often heard this
word from people who spoke to me about
the days of 1900 (as Guiteras, Agramonte
Lebredo and others), but otherwise I do
not know well this word. Is it English
or is it American, and is it well a
generally known word? I doubt of
that, because you also put it into “ ”.
I have a very good English dictionary,
written in English, which I use since
decennia in my daily work, but I
do not find there the word: fomites.
I thought if it is perhaps a local
term, introduced into the literature
by some individual member of the
Comission.
